reviewText: Yes, this is an Asian Region 5 DVD which won't play on all players, although there are multi-region players out there. Some computer DVD drives can also get around the regional encoding. That said, it's an OK transfer, a little on the choppy side. I don't think anything is really missing except the last two seconds of a scene where Laughton and Zasu Pitts discuss their common fondness for cooking and goldfish. There just seem to be a couple of instances where a scene jumped to the next when it probably should have faded to the next. No big deal. Also, they have removed the nice old Paramount logo from the opening and closing shots. However, since it is affordably priced and it is the only option currently available in digital format, I recommend buying it. Hopefully someone will bring out a nice restored version, but until then, this is still better than VHS or the increasingly rare showings on TV.
summary: OK until a restored official release is available

reviewText: Ruggles of Red Gap is as fresh today as in 1935. A solid example of "Depression Comedy," a genre that includes such films as My Man Godfrey, but often overlooked. The plot is not set in the 1930's; instead, the story takes place in 1912. However, the message of the film--that in the United States anyone can succeed in spite of their former lives--was/is a reminder to one and all that this aspect of our nation's gifts still exists. By no means is this a smug or pretentious effort. In Leo McCarey's hands, as the film would say of the United States, all things are possible. The high comedy of the picture stems from the interplay of Egbert Froud and his social climbing nouveau  riche wife Effie. Zazu Pitts and Charles Laughton (the former butler Ruggles) also provide gentler comedy than Egbert and Effie, but all characters are endearing and unforgettable. The scene in which Ruggles recites Lincoln's Gettysburg Address could have stopped the film cold in its tracks, but Laughton's eloquent delivery provides the pivotal scene in which the on-screen audience (and the viewing audience) are moved and enriched. At every level, this short film inspires and entertains. Like a George Bernard Shaw play, this is a comedy of ideas. It is a picture for everyone.
summary: One of the finest comedies every filmed

reviewText: Question: How many movies can you think of that were named after an actor? Certainly, there'sBEING JOHN MALKOVICH(1999),COME BACK TO THE FIVE AND DIME JIMMY DEAN, JIMMY DEAN(!982--VHS) andTO WONG FOO, THANKS FOR EVERYTHING, JULIE NEWMAR(1995).Now if you said RUGGLES OF RED GAP you'd be incorrect. Although Charlie Ruggles co-stars in this second remake of the comic western, the name match is coincidental. Charlie in fact doesn't even portray the title character.SYNOPSIS--While visiting Paris in 1908, Egbert Floud (Ruggles) wins from the Earl of Burnstead (Young) the services of his highly-proper butler, Marmaduke Ruggles (Laughton). Floud and his wife (Boland) bring Ruggles to their home in tiny Red Gap, WA, where the manservant is introduced as "Colonel" Ruggles.Colonel R. is a hit with local townswomen and he begins making up lies about his military exploits. Ruggles takes to his new home and popularity and after the widowed Mrs. Judson (Pitts) compliments his cooking, he determines to open a restaurant. One of Ruggles' first customers is his former British employer, who's come in search of him.Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 imdb viewer poll rating.(7.9) Ruggles Of Red Gap (1935) - Charles Laughton/Mary Boland/Charles Ruggles/Zasu Pitts/Roland Young/Lucien Littlefield (uncredited: Sarah Edwards/Heinie Conklin)
summary: Ruggles: "My father was a gentleman's gentleman... and his father before him."

reviewText: When "Ruggles" was adapted for the "Lux Radio Theatre" in 1939, host Cecil B. DeMille told an introductory story about how Charles Laughton before acting worked in the hotel trade and was more interested in the characters that roomed in such establishments than making a pound. Laughton must have learned much for whether he playing understated or over the top roles he had the audience's complete attention. This is the best example of the former for which viewers can be grateful for Laughton makes completely realistic the change that comes about this valet to and earl when he is exposed to American values. Laughton's recitation of The Gettysburg Address is one of those moments in film when the world seems to stand still. That scene was actually the brainchild of director Leo McCarey; it was not in the original Harry Leon Wilson novel or any of the stage and silent screen versions of "Ruggles" before 1935. Also not in the novel but in the movie is the presence of Ma Pettingill, Egbert Floud's supportive mother in law. Ma was a character in a separate Wilson work but was brought over for this production and played delightfully by Maude Eburne. "Ruggles of Red Gap" is Thirties film comedy that still makes you feel good.

reviewText: What distinguishes the best comedies is that between the laughter lies some underlying truths.  "Ruggles of Red Gap" contains more than it's share of belly-laughs but food for thought as well.  The film tackles classism, phony classism, free-will and ultimately universal brotherhood among men.  The film is a celebration of what is America that can only be appreciated from an outsider as represented by Marmaduke Ruggles, a man consigned to hereditary servitude in his English homeland.  Ruggles in the course of the film evolves from a solemn manservant to an assured entrepreneur.  The film is blessed by a marvelous performance by Charles Laughton who mesmerizes you throughout whether letting out a long repressed cowboy whoopee or reciting Lincoln's Gettysburg Address.  Universal is a little late letting this one out of the vaults but better late than never.  Here's hoping Universal and the other studios unearth more of these treasures.
summary: A Classic Comedy From The Thirties

reviewText: An excellent story set early in the last century about a stuffy English butler who's services are gambled away by an Earl, to an older American couple who live in the wild west.  Each tries to convert the other into their version of a model citizen but the kind, self-reliant spirit of independance from the couple and their frontier friends helps Ruggles break out of his shell with surprisingly funny results.  A western of sorts but without the shoot 'em ups, its a great comedy and a heartwarming story.  I can highly recommend it!

reviewText: Please note that I saw this movie on TV so I can't comment on the quality and features of the video transfer.The Old World meets the New World in this delightful farce from another era. Charles Laughton plays Ruggles, a proper British butler who goes to live in the American west in Red Gap, WA. To the locals his cultivated and dignified manners and speech represent culture and refinement, and soon the formerly shy, reserved butler unexpectedly finds himself the most popular man in town. In turn, Ruggles begins to appreciate the advantages of the American values of freedom and equality and opportunity.One thing leads to another and pretty soon Ruggles wants "...to make something of himself," as he says, and he starts up his own restaurant, something he could never have done in England, because it would have been inappropriate to his station. There's a very moving scene in which Ruggles recites the Gettysburg Address in a saloon when no one else could remember it.  Several of the party scenes in which the formerly reserved Ruggles begins to come out of his shell and becomes the life of the party are absolutely hilarious. Fresh from his previous role as the cruel Captain Bligh in Mutiny on the Bounty earlier that year, this shows Laughton's great range and versatility in a completely different, light-hearted, comic role.

reviewText: Laughton never gave a bad performance in his life, and this is a prime example of him in a comedic role, which he rarely was given.  To say he was perfect in it is an understatement. Ruggles nearly matches him, and Pitts shines. It's also a good lesson in American Civics, as the butler learns about American citizenship, which some of the citizens of Red Gap have taken for granted.  An utterly marvelous piece of work, and a good choice to show someone who's not interested in Westerns or classic film.  Included in the book, "Head `Em Off At the Pass! 94 Westerns You Should Watch."Head `Em Off At the Pass!: 94 Westerns You Should Watch

reviewText: This is a classic that displays Charles Laughton's talent for comedy.  At this time in his career, he usually played villains as Nero, Captain Bligh, or Inspector Javert.  In this film his character must be humble and unassuming since that is his training.  All the cast members made this a memorable film that should be enjoyed by the younger generations like myself.  They do not make films of this quality very often these days.

reviewText: This is a first class transfer from the Universal vaults. I have no problems with Studios releasing movies in this way - especially when the titles in question are otherwise lost to us or only available from pirates in the most awful quality.So I accept this type of issue as it is and not as a comparison of how DVD's are normally released.The sales potential for a 1935 B/W movie is limited - however with Laughton(probably the greatest screen actor of them all) giving a wonderful comedic performance in a typical Leo McCarey movie is just not possible to resist.This is a long forgotten gem of a movie - probably because it did not get Alist casting. However the casting is superb from top to bottom.Picture and sound Quality are excellent - I would grade this release as 95/100.I recommend this release completely.Mark Hood (Germany)

reviewText: You might call this "to uncivilize an English valet."  Charlie Ruggles works at that on Laughton in spite of his wife who wants the social value of having the valet of a lord......yeah...in the wild west.  A great added bonus is Roland Young as the lord, who alas, loses his valet in a poker game.  I have never seen him underplay so.  I guess because Laughton and Ruggles are so over the top.My favorite scene is Young and Ruggles calmly agreeing that they can not possibly attend the reception in Young's honor...........because they can't tie their ties.  Of course they escape out the window as mortified wife gets a glance from the room below.Three masters of comedy (and drama) with a wonderful supporting cast.......especially mom.

reviewText: Delightful, a film of great charm and warmth, with the great Charles Laughton delivering probably his most relaxed performance, with great support from Charles Ruggles, Roland Young, Mary Boland and the great Zasu Pitts. A real treat. One small mis-step, though, as it became clear to me today, for the first time, that the film’s message of American Equal Opportunity For All was really only expected to apply to white people. An unfortunate couple of moments of political incorrectness left a bit of a bad taste, but nothing too profound.There's a lot to enjoy here.  So enjoy!

reviewText: "My father was a gentleman's gentleman... and his father before him. And from that heritage of service miraculously there comes a man. A person of importance, however small. A man whose decisions and whose future are in his own hands."Rarely revived and never on UK TV, Leo McCarey's 1935 version of Ruggles of Red Gap was the third to reach the screen in just 17 years, but it's hard to imagine the other versions topping it. It's not a particularly credible plot, with Charlie Ruggles (not actually playing Ruggles despite the film literally having his name on it) `winning' Charles Laughton's reserved and soft-spoken gentleman's gentleman from Roland Young's vaguely lubricated English aristocrat and taking him out West with him, where his socially ambitious wife Mary Boland hopes he'll have a civilising effect on his wardrobe and manners. Naturally the opposite is the case, with the initially quietly horrified Ruggles the butler finding the Land of Opportunity - and widow Zasu Pitts - much to his liking...The comic misunderstandings and mistaken identity shenanigans are pretty much standard issue and the comedy generally more restrained and understated than expected, yet it's such a charming and delightfully good-natured film it's practically impossible not to embrace it. Ruggles the actor has the down home commonsense speak-yer-mind nature to carry off a part that could potentially be irritating thoroughly likeably, while Laughton's quiet, buttoned down performance is a marvel of understated depth, doing so little yet revealing so much. At heart there's not much to the film, but thanks to the increasingly overlooked Leo McCarey's wonderfully restrained direction it's a very pleasing mixture of the accessible sophistication of Ernst Lubitsch and a rather more unfussy take on the populism of Frank Capra that hits all the right spots without hitting the audience over the head in the process.Eureka's UK Region B-locked Blu-ray and DVD combo does the film justice with a very decent transfer, no fewer than three separate radio adaptations with Ruggles and Laughton, and audio recording of Laughton reciting the Gettysburg Address as per one of the film's most popular scenes (one that would get the film banned in Nazi Germany where the government didn't want any of that created equal guff polluting Aryan minds), and a booklet. There's also an interesting 17-minute interview with Laughton's biographer Simon Callow, who draws interesting parallels with the way the actor's own background in the family's hotel business (where Osbert Sitwell described him as looking "like an actor playing a waiter") and hatred of the British class system influenced both his approach to the film and his decision to take American citizenship.

reviewText: Leo McCarey was a competent director of sentimental stories, and a good director of melodramas, but it was in the genre of gag-based comedies that he truly excelled.  Having overseen the best Laurel and Hardy shorts (where the dictionary definition of the "slow burn" is perfectly illustrated), he went on to direct Harold Lloyd in his best talkie (THE MILKY WAY)  and the Marx Brothers in their best and most subversive film, DUCK SOUP.  Although, at first blush, RUGGLES OF RED GAP is a picture of unmitigated American chauvinism, it is, on subsequent viewings, a film with undertones at least as subversive as that of DUCK SOUP.The plot is simple: in 1908, an English valet, Ruggles (Charles Laughton) is the stake in an ill-advised poker game between his master, a down-at-heels Earl, becoming the servant of a cartoonishly vulgar American (Charles Ruggles) from Red Gap, Washington.  In America, Ruggles becomes, through inaccurate press reportage, "a personage," and for the first time in his life he realizes he is not merely "a gentleman's gentleman," but an actual man, able to "stand on his own two feet."  Along the way, a burgeoning class system within America's nouveau riche is exposed, along with the ignorance most Americans carry with regard to the founding principles that made their nation a great democracy in the first place.What is so enjoyable about this movie is watching the gradations of Laughton's performance as he slowly accepts the process of democratization.  Laughton, as Marmaduke Ruggles, elevates the "slow burn"--in which the audience is in on a cataclysmic piece of news, and is eagerly anticipating the comic reaction--to Tantric longevity in his priceless facial reactions to his changing environment.  Mary Boland, as Effie Floud, provides some of the most hilarious Franglais this side of Punch Magazine, and Roland Young, as the Earl, mutters some of the most delicious innuendo ever heard during the years of the Hays Production Code.This Region 5 (Taiwan) DVD is currently the only available form available in a digital format.  The highlights tend to burn out at times, especially in the first reel, set in Paris, where the lighting strategy is more flat.  After the move to America, the lighting is more modeled and the picture deficits become less and less noticeable.I hope this will soon be available in a restored version; until then, catch it on TV, or buy the disc if you have the right equipment--it is on a par with SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS and ONE, TWO, THREE as one of the great American comedies.
Title: N/A
